citation.abstract:
To evaluate whether there is any effect of different local anaesthetic agents on hearing loss after spinal anaesthesia.
Thirty American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) I patients without hearing problem were included in the study. Transient evoked otoacoustic emissions (TEOAE) were examined. Patients were randomly separated into two groups: Group L, 15 mg isobaric levobupivacaine application and Group B, 15 mg isobaric bupivacaine application, for spinal anaesthesia. Otoacoustic emission measurements were repeated on patients at the 24th hour after spinal anaesthesia application.
No significant difference was found in the output values of right and left ears according to the input values in group L at no kHz (p > 0.05). No significant difference was found in the output values of right and left ears according to the input values in other kHz of group B (p > 0.05).
Fifteen milligrams of isobaric bupivacaine and levobupivacaine had no significant difference on the effect of hearing loss after spinal anaesthesia. Hearing loss after spinal anaesthesia has many unknown issues, and deserves to be explored by performing many studies.
citation.title: Effects of Different Local Anaesthetics on Otoacoustic Emission Tests After Spinal Anaesthesia

author.name: Anestesia-Fabumed
author.description: Anestesia. Compartir, revisar y fomentar la realización de referencias de la Literatura Médica Latinoamericana y a sus Autores.
